@ q9za Anyway, it's a somewhat skewed story. It does not show all the consequences and only poses the MC as the absolute loser. In real life, people are not eternal and well-deserved prizes for the <best card player>. The human being learns from his mistakes and the plays can be reversed having new winners and new losers. That social dynamic is what this story hides, which presents the Fuckboy as the absolute winner (and showing the girl as a winner by getting a <best match>. But if we take into account social hierarchies, and not just the human psyche , the Fuckboy is an outcast with a bad reputation and whose lie could easily be discovered since in a school people have a well-known social identity. I've read two of Taniguchi daisuke's doujins, in which one is is where the MC wins, and this current one.

It's pleasant in that it shows the nature of humanity and it's origin. To take for yourself is to steal from another, be it a human, or a natural resource from the ground. For every winner, there will be a loser, and it is sound to say that you will more often be the loser than the winner, and in this case the hardwork the antagonist(?, guy who stole the girl), and his calculation and planned actions really shined through.

It's a good insight into seeing that concentrated intelligent work (and in this case correct use of timing) rather than brute force hardwork will make you accomplish things quicker.

As stated, the protagonist spent a solid 6 months expanding his relationship and trying to get closer to her, focusing on aimless, unplanned dates and meetings. And when the opportunity presented itself (it most likely presented itself multiple times in the past too) he failed to -

@ Dr.Granpa In these cases, like the doujin, it is the girl who finally loses, after learning of the deception. Feelings of guilt, regret, and pain arise. In that sense, Taniguchi follows the same route as any NTR author (showing the girl happy and without the worst end). We know that in IRL, a girl will almost always be tricked / humiliated by the Fuckboy, who just wants to fuck her. And Taniguchi here omits a lot to only show a part of the whole. It becomes a bit hypocritical since the lesson does not only apply to the MC. But, well, I don't see everything negative. What I rescue from Taniguchi's work is that at least he has built a coherent (somewhat realistic) situation about how a Fuckboy can win over a girl.

@Dr.Grandpa Well, The doujin has a message that shows the MC as a loser ... but to construct such a message Taniguchi Daisuke is hypocritical since he does not dare to write the real consequences: he only writes what suits him so that only the MC looks like the loser and everything seems to be his fault. Taniguchi omits too many things: 1) Once the Fuckboy gets what he wanted, he just stops acting like the gentleman in front of the girl 2) The girl IS NOT GOING TO BECOME HIS BITCH. On the contrary, she will realize that (sooner or later) that everything was a lie: and it is not difficult not to know, since at school it is easy to know the profile of a student. 3) The girl either ends up alone or will look for the MC. Maybe they will never come back or maybe they will, but that would be the true ending. This story would be realistic if the Fuckboy was a person with sincere intentions from the beginning, so he would not have to always act.

You have the boyfriend who's a bit of a wet blanket that doesn't know exactly what to do in a relationship, but then you have this cunning, manipulative asshole who essentially does the shit that Dennis from It's Always Sunny does.  I liked the irony that they were both competing for the same spot in the soccer team, which shou won, and they are, unbeknownst to shou, competing for the same girl, which the other guy wins.  It would be better if the guy was actually in love with her, and not just manipulating her for sex and out of spite, but that makes it all the more tragic, which I feel is one of the goals of NTR works. 
I'm glad shou was able to accept it, as he realized he didn't really understand her, and may have just convinced himself to love her, so good on him I guess.
